data.title: RU2729231C1 - Method of producing dicobalt octacarbonyl - Google Patents
data.meta_description:
FIELD: chemistry. 
     SUBSTANCE: invention relates to chemical industry, specifically to a technology for producing dicobalt octacarbonyl Co 2 (CO) 8 , used in particular for producing high-purity metallic cobalt, depositing cobalt-containing coatings, a catalyst for oxosynthesis processes. Reactor is successively loaded with aqueous cobalt (II) acetate, hexane and water with subsequent blowing with nitrogen and supply of carbon monoxide and hydrogen, heating the reaction mixture in a reactor at rate of 10Â Â°C per minute, holding for 60 minutes at pressure of 25â30 MPa and temperature of 170Â Â°C, followed by separation of aqueous and organic phase and separation of dicobalt octacarbonyl from organic phase by low-temperature crystallisation. 
     EFFECT: low-temperature crystallisation increases output of target product (97_6Â % of theoretically possible) and purity thereof. 
     1 cl, 1 ex

Ð Ð½ÐµÐ´Ð¾ÑÑÐ°ÑÐºÐ°Ð¼ ÑÐºÐ°Ð·Ð°Ð½Ð½Ð¾Ð³Ð¾ ÑÐ¿Ð¾ÑÐ¾Ð±Ð° Ð¾ÑÐ½Ð¾ÑÐ¸ÑÑÑ Ð½ÐµÐ²ÑÑÐ¾ÐºÐ¸Ð¹ Ð²ÑÑ Ð¾Ð´ Ð¿ÑÐ¾Ð´ÑÐºÑÐ° Ð¸ Ð±Ð¾Ð»ÑÑÐ¾Ð¹ ÑÐ°ÑÑ Ð¾Ð´ Ð¾ÐºÐ¸ÑÐ¸ ÑÐ³Ð»ÐµÑÐ¾Ð´Ð°, Ð½ÐµÐ¾Ð±Ñ Ð¾Ð´Ð¸Ð¼ÑÐ¹ Ð´Ð»Ñ Ð¿ÑÐ¾Ð´ÑÐ²ÐºÐ¸ ÑÐµÐ°ÐºÑÐ¾ÑÐ°.Traditional methods of producing dicobalt octacarbonyl are reduced to the reaction of metallic cobalt or its compounds (oxides, salts) with carbon monoxide or a mixture of carbon monoxide and gaseous hydrogen at high pressures and temperatures (Syntheses of inorganic compounds: in 3 vol. / Ch. Ed. By W. Jolly - M .: Mir, 1966 .-- T. 1. - 278 p.). So, there is a known method (Jolly WL Synthetic inorganic chemistry / WL Jolly. - New Jersey, 1964), according to which 7.5 g of CoCO 3 and 75 ml of a low-boiling solvent (paraffin series) are loaded into a shaking autoclave with a capacity of 300 ml; the autoclave is purged with carbon monoxide to remove air, after which a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen (1: 1) is introduced at a pressure of 240 excess atmospheres. The autoclave is heated to 150-160 Â° C, kept at this temperature for 3 hours, cooled to room temperature and gas is released into the hood. The resulting dark solution is filtered through paper and kept at about -10 Â° C overnight. The solvent is decanted from the dark red crystals. The crystals are dried in a stream of dry nitrogen to obtain ~ 6 g of dry product with a yield of ~ 55%. The disadvantages of this method include a low yield of the product and a large consumption of carbon monoxide required for blowing the reactor.

Japan. - 1962. - V. 35. - P 865-869), according to which 16.6 g of Co 2 CO 3 are dispersed in a steel autoclave in 180 ml of a benzene solution containing 0.47 g of pyridine. 1.71 g of dicobalt octacarbonyl are slowly added to the resulting dispersion, after which the autoclave is sealed and a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen in a ratio of 1: 1 is introduced until a pressure of 200 kg / cm 2 is reached. The resulting mixture is heated to 110 Â° C and maintained at this temperature. The author does not indicate the yield of cobalt octacarbonyl. The disadvantages of this process include the need to introduce a "seed" - crystalline octacarbonyl dicobalt at the beginning of the synthesis.

Continuous manufacture of solutions of cobalt carbonyl and cobalt carbonyl hydride in an organic solvent / Strohmeyer M., Nienburg HJ, Kummer R., Hohenschutz H .; applicant and patent holder BASF Aktiengesellschaft, Germany. - publ. 05/18/1976. - 3 p.) in organic solvents, partially miscible or immiscible with water, by treating an aqueous solution of cobalt salts with a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen at temperatures of 50-200 Â° C and pressures 50-500 atm. As an organic solvent partially miscible with water, n-butyl alcohol is used, which contains cobalt octacarbonyl, cobalt hydrocarbonyl or their mixture in an amount of 0.02-4.0%. In this case, a solution of these carbonyls in n-butyl alcohol is fed into the reaction mixture together with the supply of a mixture of gases - carbon monoxide and hydrogen while maintaining a turbulent flow. The disadvantages of this method include the complexity of the technological process and the need to use a "seed" -octacarbonyl dicobalt, hydrocarbonyl cobalt or their mixture at the beginning of the synthesis.

A method of obtaining a catalyst for the hydroformylation process / Khvorov A.P., Gavrilova V.M., Gvozdovsky G.N. ., Shmelev R.A .; applicant and patentee Khvorov A.P., RF. - publ. 20.06.1999. - 8 p.) By interaction of aqueous solutions of cobalt salts of lower organic acids C 1 -C 3 with a compound containing higher organic acids, at an elevated temperature, characterized in that as a compound containing higher organic acids, the by-products of the hydroformylation reaction are used, formed after the regeneration of cobalt with acetic acid and having a boiling point above 160 Â° C at a residual pressure of 50-200 mm. rt. Art. pretreated with air or oxygen-containing gas at a temperature of 80-140 Â° C for 3-6 hours.
